isis.stitle: STEERING COLUMN ASSEMBLY, TILT/TELESCOPING - ProStar - REMOVE AND INSTALL PROCEDURES - CLOCK SPRING

step1.para: Remove the horn pad by placing both hands on top of the horn pad and using your fingertips underneath the top leading edge of the horn pad to gently pull upward toward you ( Figure 2, Items 1 and 2).
Disconnect the wire connector from the back of the horn pad ( Figure 2, Item 2).
Place a reference mark on the steering column shaft and steering wheel to aid in the alignment of the steering wheel during installation procedures ( Figure 3, Item 3).
Disconnect the steering wheel harness connector ( Figure 3, Item 4).
Remove the retaining nut from the steering wheel and steering column ( Figure 3, Items 1 and 2).
Attach the appropriate steering wheel puller to the steering wheel. Apply enough pressure with the puller to loosen the steering wheel from the steering column ( Figure 4, Items 1, 2, and 3).
Remove the steering wheel from the steering column ( Figure 4, Items 1 and 3).
Remove five screws from the top steering column outer cover.
Remove the top steering column outer cover and the top steering column inner cover.
Disconnect the wire connector from the clock spring.
Verify that the wheels are straight, then tape the top cover of the clock spring to the bottom housing of the clock spring.
Remove three machine screws from the clock spring.
Remove the clock spring from the steering column.

caution.para: Read and follow directions for the clock spring installation very carefully. This device will break if not properly installed.

item.para: If the clock spring binds or the tape that was installed during the removal procedures is broken, perform step 1.
If the clock spring is secured with tape, skip step 1.

step1.para: To ensure that the spring is centered, do the following:

item.para: Turn the clock spring cover counterclockwise until it is locked.
Turn the clock spring cover clockwise 4.5 turns.
Align the arrows on the clock spring cover and mounting body (Figure 8, Item 3)
Tape the top cover of the clock spring to the bottom housing of the clock spring.

step1.para: Install the clock spring onto the steering column and secure the clock spring with three machine screws ( Figure 7, Items 1, 2, and 3). Torque machine screws to 10 to 25 lbf-in (1.1 to 2.8 N•m).
Connect the wire connector to the clock spring ( Figure 7, Items 1 and 4).

note.para: There are four standard screws and one machine screw used for mounting the top steering column outer cover. Be sure to install the machine screw into the top mounting hole, as this position secures the top steering column outer cover to the steering column.

step1.para: Install the top steering column outer cover and top steering column inner cover ( Figure 6, Items 1 and 2). The top steering column covers must capture the top bellow and plastic ring of the steering column bellow.
Secure the top steering column outer cover to the top steering column inner cover with five screws ( Figure 6, Items 1, 2, and 3). Torque screws to 10 to 25 lbf-in (1.1 to 2.8 N•m).

caution.para: Make sure the clip on the top of the clock spring properly aligns with the slot in steering wheel and that the clock spring wiring is fed through the appropriate hole in the steering wheel. The clock spring could be damaged if these components are not aligned properly during installation.

note.para: If a new steering wheel is being installed, place the new steering wheel next to the removed steering wheel and copy the reference mark that was made during the removal procedures onto the new steering wheel.

step1.para: Position the steering wheel on the steering column, making sure to align the marks that were made during the removal procedures ( Figure 3, Item 3).
Install the retaining nut on the steering wheel and steering column ( Figure 3, Items 1 and 2). Torque nut to 60 to 65 lbf-ft (81 to 88 N•m).
Connect the steering wheel harness connector ( Figure 3, Item 4).
Connect the wire connector on the back of the horn pad ( Figure 2, Item 2).

caution.para: Do not attempt to snap all four horn pad retaining posts in at the same time by hitting the steering wheel in the center, otherwise damage may result.

step1.para: Lay the horn pad on top of the steering wheel and align the four horn pad retaining posts directly on top of their respective mating holes. Using the palm of your hand, gently tap each of the four corners of the horn pad starting with the lower right, then lower left, then upper right, and finishing with the upper left ( Figure 2, Items 1 and 2).
